Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition (said to be limestone in register); back rather well-detailed with modelled head and clypeus, prothorax and elytra indicated respectively by single and double lines; underside bearing incised hieroglyphic inscription arranged vertically, naming Menkheperra; scarab sign framed by short vertical lines; longitudinally pierced; remains of turquoise blue glaze; white core of fine texture.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Egyptian Museum, Cairo. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The name of Menkheperra appears on a wide range of scarabs and scaraboids and does not necessarily refer to Thutmosis III: it was also a popular motto associated to Amun-Ra (Jaeger 1982). For another Menkheperra scarab in glazed composition: BM 1886,0401.1642. Jaeger, B. 1982, Essai de classification et datation des scarabées Menkhéperrê. Fribourg.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.104) (phase 3)
